image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has increased the cash rate to 4.1 per cent at its June meeting, citing "persistent" and "ongoing" high inflation. It's the highest cash rate since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: Reserve Bank lifts cash rate to 4.1pc, but won't rule out 'further tightening' to tackle inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
If only 1/3 of properties in Australia have mortgages - surely continuing to rise interest rates for a small percentage of people is a poor way of controlling inflation? 
Have they considered other methods of lowering inflation that doesn't disproportionally impact a certain population? - Mick. I think we do need to be more creative in how we combat inflation. A couple of months ago, I wrote about an idea that John Maynard Keynes came up with to control inflation during WWII. Friedrich Hayek, the Austrian economist who really detested Keynes's influence on policymakers, even had to admit the idea was "ingenious." Now, the possibility of using an idea like this would depend on the nature of the problem that's causing the inflation, and the nature of the inflation itself, but I think it helps to open one's mind to all possibilities - so we can see the world with fresh eyes sometimes. Could something like this work in the future?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Alternative tools to tackle inflation?

featuredLink.title: Is there a better way to kill inflation than raising interest rates?

children.content:
If only 1/3 of properties in Australia have mortgages - surely continuing to rise interest rates for a small percentage of people is a poor way of controlling inflation? 
Have they considered other methods of lowering inflation that doesn't disproportionally impact a certain population?
- Mick
I think we
do
need to be more creative in how we combat inflation.
A couple of months ago, I wrote about an idea that John Maynard Keynes came up with to control inflation during WWII.
Friedrich Hayek, the Austrian economist who really detested Keynes's influence on policymakers, even had to admit the idea was "ingenious."

Now, the possibility of using an idea like this would depend on the nature of the problem that's causing the inflation, and the nature of the inflation itself, but I think it helps to open one's mind to all possibilities - so we can see the world with fresh eyes sometimes.
Could something like this work in the future?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Why is nobody mentioning that interest rates will rise monthly until the 2 per cent inflation target is reached?  Why do we have to have this monthly speculation
about ‘will they or won’t they’?  It’s about time the RBA were up front about the strategy, and made it abundantly clear that interest rate rises will occur monthly and indefinitely.   - Stuart. Interest rate rises won't occur monthly and indefinitely. We can blame economists for lots of things, but they did learn a lot from the misjudgements they made in the late 1980s and early 1990s when driving the overnight cash rate above 18%, and keeping rates too high for too long. That's not to say these rate rises won't drive unemployment higher. The RBA itself is expecting the unemployment rate to rise from 3.7% (currently) to 4.5% by mid-2025. But I haven't seen a single economist suggest that rates will just keep rising. We're living in a very different world today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indefinite rate rises? That won't happen

children.content:
Why is nobody mentioning that interest rates will rise monthly until the 2 per cent inflation target is reached?  Why do we have to have this monthly speculation
about ‘will they or won’t they’?  It’s about time the RBA were up front about the strategy, and made it abundantly clear that interest rate rises will occur monthly and indefinitely.
- Stuart
Interest rate rises won't occur monthly and indefinitely.

We can blame economists for lots of things, but they did learn a lot from the misjudgements they made in the late 1980s and early 1990s when driving the overnight cash rate above 18%, and keeping rates too high for too long.
That's not to say these rate rises won't drive unemployment higher. The RBA itself is expecting the unemployment rate to rise from 3.7% (currently) to 4.5% by mid-2025.
But I haven't seen a single economist suggest that rates will just keep rising. We're living in a very different world today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages. "Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement. "While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued." In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's slightly bigger than expected rise in minimum and award wages, which was the highest in decades. "Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed. "Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year. "At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up." In contrast — Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week. (Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What has Philip Lowe said about the rate rise?

children.content: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages.
"Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement.

"While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued."
In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's
slightly bigger than expected rise in
minimum and award wages
, which was the highest in decades.
"Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed.
"Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year.
"At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up."
In contrast — Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week.
(Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)
